stem: A 29-year-old client with preeclampsia is being monitored in the antepartum unit. Based on the documentation in the High-Risk Triage & Lab Portal tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: New onset of right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain.
Background: Admitted yesterday for BP 154/98. Proteinuria confirmed.
Assessment: Client reports nausea and 'burning' pain under her right ribs.
Recommendation: Immediate HELLP screen.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 168/112, HR 104, RR 20, SpO2 96%. Edema increased to 3+.

actionOptions.text: Initiate or continuing Magnesium Sulfate infusion for seizure prophylaxis
Prepare for imminent delivery regardless of gestational age
Reassure the client that RUQ pain is a normal sign of labor
Apply cold packs to the liver area to reduce inflammation

parameterOptions.text: Signs of bruising, petechiae, or oozing (DIC logic)
Epigastric or Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ) pain intensity
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This client is progressing from preeclampsia to HELLP Syndrome (c2), as confirmed by the sudden drop in platelets (< 100k), rise in liver enzymes (ALT/AST), and hemolysis (Bilirubin/Schistocytes). RUQ pain is a hallmark sign of hepatic involvement. Priority actions are preventing eclamptic seizures with Magnesium (a1) and preparing for delivery (a2), as HELLP is an obstetric emergency. Parameters focus on the risk of DIC/bleeding (p1) and monitoring the liver pain (p2).
clinicalPearls: Schistocytes on a blood smear are 'helmet cells'â€”fragments of RBCs chopped up by microclots, confirming hemolysis.
Platelets < 100,000 is the 'Low Platelets' part of HELLP.
Delivery is the only definitive treatment for HELLP; however, corticosteroids (Betamethasone) may be given if the 24-48 hour delay for fetal lung maturity is deemed safe by the provider.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking RUQ pain is just 'reflux' or 'gastritis'.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In a preeclamptic patient, GI pain is NEVER just GI pain. It is liver stretching, which means the patient is 'crashing' into HELLP or Eclampsia.

mnemonic.title: HELLP Hazards
mnemonic.expansion: H-Hemolysis. E-Epigastric pain. L-Little platelets. L-Liver failure. P-Pre-term delivery.
